question: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. The patient started experiencing these symptoms shortly after arriving home from going out to eat at a seafood restaurant. His symptoms progressed and now he reports having an odd metallic taste in his mouth, diffuse pruritus, and blurry vision. His temperature is 99.0В°F (37.2В°C), blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg, pulse is 50/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam reveals bradycardia and an inability of the patient to differentiate hot versus cold; no rash can be appreciated on exam. What is the most likely etiology of this patientвЂ™s symptoms?

content.source_1: The prior probability of seafood poisoning is relatively high due to the fact that the symptoms occurred shortly after the patient consumed seafood. We will start with a posterior probability of 50%. When seafood poisoning occurs, one common type is Ciguatera poisoning, which is associated with consuming contaminated reef fish and causes gastrointestinal symptoms, unusual sensations, and bradycardia. This raises the posterior probability to 65%. The presence of a metallic taste, pruritus, and visual disturbances, are also commonly seen in Ciguatera poisoning, which raises the probability further to 80%. Another characteristic symptom of Ciguatera poisoning is temperature reversal (where hot feels cold and cold feels hot), which he seems to have (an inability to differentiate hot versus cold), taking the posterior probability up to 95%. The absence of a rash does not exclude Ciguatera poisoning, thus the high probability remains. Given these symptoms and his recent seafood consumption, the most likely etiology of the patient's symptoms is Ciguatera poisoning.
content.source_2: The patient presented symptoms shortly after having a meal at a seafood restaurant, and these symptoms include nausea, vomiting, an odd metallic taste, pruritus (itchiness), blurry vision, bradycardia (slow heart rate), and difficulty differentiating hot versus cold. These are consistent with the symptoms of scombroid poisoning or histamine fish poisoning, which can occur after consumption of improperly stored or spoiled fish, especially certain types of fish like mackerel and tuna. The symptoms occur due to high levels of histamine and possibly other substances. Immediate onset of symptoms after eating fish and the presence of classic signs such as flushing, rash, and hypotension further support the diagnosis.
content.source_3: The symptoms of nausea, vomiting, metallic taste, pruritus (itching), blurry vision, bradycardia, and temperature sensation abnormalities this patient experiences after eating at a seafood restaurant strongly suggest scombroid poisoning. Scombroid poisoning, also known as histamine fish poisoning, is an illness that occurs after consuming improperly stored fish, such as mackerel or tuna, which have high histamine content due to bacterial overgrowth and subsequent decarboxylation of histidine. The clinical presentation often includes symptoms that are similar to an allergic reaction, including flushing, pruritus, and gastrointestinal upset. The temperature sensation abnormalities and bradycardia are likely secondary to the histamine-mediated vasodilation and may not be seen in all cases of scombroid poisoning.
